column2: All first forenames given to babies between 1974 to 2024
The data table was originally published at 9.30am of Thursday, 20 March 2024.
Scotland, council areas
National Records of Scotland (NRS)
Demographic Statistics and Vital Events
Baby name statistics are compiled from first names recorded in the ‘child’s forename(s)’ part of the entry of the registration of the birth
By law, all births have to be registered, and the details are sent by local registrars to the National Records of Scotland (NRS).
The statistics are based only on births which were registered up to the 11 February 2025.
Baby name statistics refer to the births registered in Scotland.
All births which occur in Scotland should be registered in Scotland, even if the people involved are residents of other countries.
These figures do not include any names that were given to babies who were stillborn.
Baby names statistics do not include names given to babies of Scottish residents where the birth occurred outwith Scotland.
The statistics are based on the exact spelling of the name given on the birth certificate.
Different spellings (for example Stephen, Steven; Holly, Hollie; Callum, Calum) were counted separately.
Variants based on the same name were counted separately (for example ‘Ben’ and ‘Benjamin’ are different names, likewise ‘Agnes’ and ‘Senga’, and ‘Tony’ and ‘Anthony’).
Accents were ignored, so (for example) ‘Chloe’, ‘Chloé’, ‘Chloë’. ‘Chloè’ and ‘Chlöe’ are all counted as the same name: ‘Chloe’.
Births where the name of the baby is not stated are excluded from all the ranks.

Names with a count of 2 or less in total within Scotland have been suppressed (an exemption applies under Section 38 of the Freedom of Information (Scotland) Act 2002) in order to protect the confidentiality of individuals.
